narratives.question_text: How clearly did the instructor define the topic of study?
comments: I felt the topic was well defined and clearly articulated where we would proceed with the course, I knew what to expect generally. A few times it would have been nice to have the next chapters of the book to look ahead but this will not be an issue once the text is published.
It took a while to understand the definition, but I believe that was a part of the learning process.
The semester began with a useful overview of the importance of the topic and stories to illustrate how the topic applies practically to the industry.

narratives.question_text: How clearly did the instructor outline the expectation for the course, classroom activity and homework?
comments: The syllabus was particularly excellent because it highlighted the topics and homework covered in the entire semester without deviating in plan.

There was some variation at times between the expectation on the homework versus the expectation on the test. it was difficult to know how much detail was required at times, as many of our in class examples and discussions involved rounding and altering numbers slightly "between friends" none of which would be acceptable on the test.

The overall expectations and marking structure were clear. However there were sometimes things that weren't marked incorrect on homework that were subsequently marked incorrect on an exam. I feel like the homework markings should accurately identify expectations for exams, so as to allow students to best prepare.
The syllabus clearly stated the expectations for homework and tests.
Which homework is assigned and when it is due is very clearly laid out, but exactly what's expected on the homework is not. It's not always clear how much is required.

narratives.question_text: How well were individual class sessions prepared and presented?
comments: Classes had a clarity in topic and fit well within the allotted time.
I particularly enjoy and value discussion of real world applications of these principles and practices. There was some. I could use more.

narratives.question_text: How well did lectures fit within the boundaries of the course?
comments: We sometimes got derailed talking about people's individual experiences,or discussing topics we had not reached in the syllabus yet
The lectures really cleared up any questions I had based on reading the textbook. It was always very easy to ask questions.

It is often too tempting to just read along with the text instead of listening to what Ben is saying since they are so similar. I think it would be very helpful to read in advance, maybe even do part or all of the assignments ahead of time so that class can be used for discussion of the material. Right now, class periods feel like little more than an assigned time to have Ben read us the textbook. While this is still somewhat useful, I think the time can be put to better use if we read and attempt a problem or 2 before the start of class, since that is when we have processed and begin to understand the material. Only then do we come up with good questions to ask. Maybe it could be helpful to have a brief review/Q&A session covering the previous class' material at the start of each class?

Although heavy at times I do not think I would have gotten as much out of the class without it. It really held me focus in on the sections I was struggling with and gain a clearer understanding of the material.

I thought the work was where I learned the most, actually going through the problems. I thought it would be beneficial to build in time to review the homework when it is returned, so we could better understand where our mistakes came from.

While it was hard to keep up with the homework during heavy work times in production assignments, the homework is where i learned the most. Having a two week grace period for all homework is a really great thing that takes the pressure off and the volume not feel too horrible.
Never too much; never too little. It was easy to do the homework in the time allotted.

I felt as though the workload took up a regular and large part of our time outside of class, and that it was a challenge to manage at times. However I also felt as though there was not enough homework. More practice would have led to better results on my part, but I'm not sure how more time could be found to dedicate to that.
The homework was balanced well between a reasonable amount to complete in a timely manner and a useful amount for absorbing the information at hand.

narratives.question_text: How available was the instructor for help outside the classroom?
comments: Did not seek instructor's help outside of classroom. TA was always available.
As long as you made an appointment in advance he was always willing to meet with us.
Don't know, never really sought them out, have heard they were quite helpful to others though.
I turned to the TA with questions and was never disappointed.
The instructor and TA were both readily available for answering questions outside of class.
I never pursued Ben's help outside of class. Our TA, Mike Best, was extremely available for help outside of class though, and I made use of his assistance regularly as needed.
I did not seek out additional help outside the classroom aside from quick questions after class or of the T.A.

narratives.question_text: How useful were assignments in furthering an understanding of the topic?
comments: See question #5
I felt like I learned most from the homework and tests
Doing the problem sets really helped drive home the points discussed in class and the textbook.
The only way to learn it was to do the homework.
Doing the assignments are what helped my understanding of the material the most.

narratives.question_text: If tests were given, how fairly did they measure knowledge gained?
comments: Not all topics covered in the tests. More short answers may be able to elicit comprehension without a significant impact on the length of the test.
It was sometimes difficult to know the level of detail required to show our work
The tests were really fair, and based on lectures, the book, and homework assignments. It was also great that credit is given for the math procedures, as well as the answer.
They provided a fair and in-depth questioning to test our ability to apply the concepts in a realistic manner (with the text available).

The test questions were mostly fair questions as I would expect from a test on those chapters. However, it seemed like there were a few low-point questions that were there to test if we could find some random tidbit hidden in the text (for instance, something about a rule of thumb for estimating the weight of plywood) more than it tested our understanding of the material. It's a minor note, but worth mentioning.

narratives.question_text: How useful was this course in preparing you for production work?
comments: I it applies directly to my production work
I've used some of this math already in production work.
I had the opportunity to use what we learned in class three times in the budgeting process.
In-class examples were useful for outlining how the concepts should be applied in practical production situations.

The class thus far has backed up my experience and intuitive understanding of how structural stage carpentry works as well expanded my thinking in this area. I feel very well prepared for production work, but am looking forward to digging into more complex areas of this topic.

narratives.question_text: How would you evaluate the instructor's knowledge of the material?
comments: Wrote the book. Kept material up-to-date.
not only does he have a vast knowledge of the subject matter but is very passionate about it
He wrote the book... So I'd say it's pretty good. It seemed to really shine when we discussed problems that weren't just taken directly out of the book.
I especially appreciate how, if we manage to ask a question Ben doesn't know the answer to, he will call whoever he needs to in order to get an accurate answer.

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments on such topics as: what worked best about the course, suggested improvements, class materials, etc.
comments: The classes is excellent overall. I particularly enjoyed the moments in class where production examples were used to highlight principles in the book. My only suggestion would be to inject more production-related examples that carried the class and carry various calculations on the white board rather than look at examples in the book. I find that I will always look at the examples while working on homework anyway, so I don't find it as necessary to go through some of the examples during class.

The most important lesson in the computation was to always use the units, and to use the same format in running the equations: write the equation with the variables, then write the equation with the numbers substituted for the variables (with absolutely no calculation done, even simple. subtraction or addition), then run the calculation. This made problem solving where an answer went wrong much simpler. It also made it easier to understand what was going on in a more general sense. Clarity in doing the math is essential. Adding notes about what is happening (e.g. "CF not used b/c beam is Southern Pine") was also useful. This is a simple lesson, but it made a real difference in engaging with the material. Some of the material may benefit from physical demonstration. The tension and compression faces of a beam, for example, could easily be demonstrated by writing "tension" on one face and "compression" on the other of an elastic material, such as a foam cushion. Again, a simplistic example, but it may help some pupils to better grasp the basic concepts. Some actual beams and columns could make a course on structural design a little more accessible to people that haven't really been exposed to the material before. If nothing else, the suggested summer reading of "Why Buildings Fall Down" should be encouraged more strongly. Hitting the ground running makes a big difference for First Year students in their First Semester.

I think this is a great course and although it was a struggle for me I learned a lot. I owe this not only to my professor but also to a wonderful TA who always went out oh his way to meet with us day nights or weekends. Having the 2 week grace period for turning in homework was fantastic. Although I always strove to get it in on time, there were some weeks where having a few extra days penalty free made all the difference. My one complaint was not getting out first test back before having to take the second one. Knowing how I did on problems on the first test would have help on the second. However I understand the circumstances and reasons why it was not possible.

I enjoyed the course, and would only recommend a tighter feedback loop for tests, and possibly a chance to review homework upon its return to catch why mistakes were made early on so they don't track through multiple homeworks.
This was a great class. I really loved it.

I found it most helpful when I was able to review homework with the TA and talk through my errors. If there was an opportunity to re-do homework following that kind of a meeting for increased points it would insentivise further practice when the opportunity presented itself. Probably not the best idea for people who are missing a point here or there, but perhaps when there is a failing grade on a homework assignment it would be helpful both for the students learning and for their grade.

The single biggest improvement I can suggest for this class is to reduce the turnaround time on homework and tests. Since the lectures progress so steadily and the homework follows each class, it would be immensely beneficial to have each homework assignment back the next day, so as to review it and correct any misunderstandings before completing the next homework assignment, which often builds directly upon the previous assignment. I'm aware that what I'm suggesting is a fairly large workload for someone, but in a subject where each concept tends to be stacked pretty squarely upon the previous, catching misunderstandings quickly and correcting them promptly would help keep people from floundering.
